title: Type mismatch errors through generic enums could be clearer

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
### Code

[playground](https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=stable&mode=debug&edition=2021&gist=72b06b26d9fd62ef4268a31b59c4c7dc)

```rust
enum A<T> {
    X(T)
}

fn f() -> A<()> {
    A::X(0_u32)
}

fn main() {}
```

### Current output

```
error[E0308]: mismatched types
 --> src/main.rs:6:10
  |
6 |     A::X(0_u32)
  |     ---- ^^^^^ expected `()`, found `u32`
  |     |
  |     arguments to this enum variant are incorrect
  |
note: tuple variant defined here
 --> src/main.rs:2:5
  |
2 |     X(T)
  |     ^
```

Due to the use of generics, seeing the definition of the enum variant doesn't really get at the root of the problem.

### Ideal output

```
error[E0308]: mismatched types
 --> src/main.rs:6:10
  |
6 |     A::X(0_u32)
  |     ---- ^^^^^ expected `()`, found `u32`
  |     |
  |     arguments to this enum variant are incorrect

note: expected `()` due to the function signature specifying the generic type for `A`:
  |
5 | fn f() -> A<()> {
  |             ^^
```

### Impact

This can happen with `Option` or `Result`, which are common return types.
